issues.text: was there a lock-out by the Company?

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, was there a lock-out by the Company? The learned Advocate for the appellants first contends that the notices use the same words as are used in the definition of a lock-out in s. 2 1  of the Act and therefore by those notices the Company

issues.text: Did the notices then effect a discharge?

anchor.surface_text: Did the notices then effect a discharge ? We agree with the Courts below that they did. The learned Advocate for the appellants contends that the two notices taken together make it perfectly clear that there was no discharge of any employee prior to 11 a. m. of April 28, 1953.

issues.text: whether a discharge of employees by an employer amounts to a lock-out

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether a discharge of employees by an employer amounts to a lock-out. It is said that the words used in the definition of a lock-out, namely, the refusal by an employer to continue to employ any number of persons employed by him cover the discharge of employees by an employer.

issues.text: about the propriety of the sanction

anchor.surface_text: The last point raised is about the propriety of the sanction. Section 34 1  of the Act provides, No court shall take cognisance of any offence punishable under this Act save on complaint made by or under the authority of the appropriate Government.

arguments.claim: The notices use the same words as are used in the definition of a lock-out in s. 2(1) of the Act and therefore by those notices the Company locked-out the men.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the appellants first contends that the notices use the same words as are used in the definition of a lock-out in s. 2 1  of the Act and therefore by those notices the Company locked-out the men. We think that this argument is unfound

arguments.court_reasoning: Words are not the same ('considered to be no longer employed' vs 'refusal to continue to employ'); must read in respective contexts; notices meant discharge, definition does not contemplate discharge.

arguments.claim: The notices did not effect a discharge till April 28, 1953, and they had in the meantime resulted in a lock-out of the workers from April 10, 1953, in the sense that their services had not been terminated but they had not been allowed to attend to their duties.

arguments.claim: A discharge of employees by an employer does not amount to a lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether a discharge of employees by an employer amounts to a lock-out. It is said that the words used in the definition of a lock-out... cover the discharge of employees by an employer. The contention so raised was rejected by the Lab

arguments.claim: The sanction is valid as facts constituting the offence were placed before the sanctioning authority.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, ample evidence in this case... which clearly establishes that the entire facts connected with the offence had been placed before the sanctioning authority and the sanction had been granted on a consideration of them.

holdings.text: The notices issued by the Company effected a discharge of the workers on April 10, 1953, and not a lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: Did the notices then effect a discharge ? We agree with the Courts below that they did. The learned Advocate for the appellants contends that the two notices taken together make it perfectly clear that there was no discharge of any employee prior to 11 a. m. of April 28, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain meaning of April 8 notice deems workers no longer employed after 2pm April 10 if no willingness recorded; April 25 notice confirms discharge from that date with only formal roll removal pending; Labour Minister treated them as discharged.

holdings.text: There was no lock-out by the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, was there a lock-out by the Company? The learned Advocate for the appellants first contends that the notices use the same words as are used in the definition of a lock-out in s. 2 1  of the Act and therefore by those notices the Company

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words in notices differ from s.2(1) definition and context indicates discharge, not mere refusal to employ while retaining relation; agrees with lower courts' finding.

holdings.text: A discharge of employees by an employer does not amount to a lock-out under section 2(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether a discharge of employees by an employer amounts to a lock-out. It is said that the words used in the definition of a lock-out, namely, the refusal by an employer to continue to employ any number of persons employed by him cover the discharge of employees by an employer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Labour Appellate Tribunal in Presidency Jute Mills case; excludes severance of employment relation; harmonious construction avoids conflict with ss.22,23,33,2(oo),25F; policy requires allowing immediate discharge for misconduct; definition contemplates temporary refusal without termination.

holdings.text: The sanction granted by the Government under section 34(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, to file the complaint is valid and unobjectionable.

anchor.surface_text: The last point raised is about the propriety of the sanction. Section 34 1  of the Act provides, No court shall take cognisance of any offence punishable under this Act save on complaint made by or under the authority of the appropriate Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ample evidence shows all facts of offence placed before sanctioning authority, considered before grant; follows Gokalchand precedent allowing proof by evidence even if facts not on sanction face.

holdings.text: The strikes were illegal under section 24(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and the appellants committed an offence under section 27 by instigating them; the appeal fails.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case is that the strikes of April 11, to April 20, 1953, and April 27, 1953, were illegal and the appellants had instigated them. The appellants have not in this Court challenged the finding of the Courts below that the strikes took place

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants concede strikes occurred and they instigated; no lock-out so s.24(3) exception inapplicable; strikes contravene s.22 in public utility service; lower court convictions confirmed.

holdings.text: Sentence modified to period already served plus fine of Rs.100 or 15 days simple imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: We feel, therefore, that the appeal must fail. We think it right however in the circumstances of this case and in view of the long lapse of time since the case started, to modify the sentence passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Considering circumstances and lapse of time since events.

anchor.surface_text: Did the notices then effect a discharge ? We agree with the Courts below that they did. The learned Advocate for the appellants contends that the two notices taken together make it perfectly clear that there was no discharge of any employee prior to 11 a. m. of April 28, 1953.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly resolves the issue by stating that discharge does not amount to a lock-out.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether a discharge of employees by an employer amounts to a lock-out. It is said that the words used in the definition of a lock-out, namely, the refusal by an employer to continue to employ any number of persons employed by him cover the discharge of employees by an employer.

We feel, therefore, that the appeal must fail. We think it right however in the circumstances of this case and in view of the long lapse of time since the  1  1952 L.A.C. 62.  1948  L.R. 75 I.A. 30. case started, to modify the sentence passed.

anchor.surface_text: The last point raised is about the propriety of the sanction. Section 34 1  of the Act provides, No court shall take cognisance of any offence punishable under this Act save on complaint made by or under the authority of the appropriate Government.

We feel, therefore, that the appeal must fail. We think it right however in the circumstances of this case and in view of the long lapse of time since the  1  1952 L.A.C. 62.  1948  L.R. 75 I.A. 30. case started, to modify the sentence passed.
